ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to write humorous texts that you would see in McSweeney's or Reductress, etc., with a focus on tone, character, narrative, and texture.

Not much. I did a lot of writing, which was probably good practice. But trying to extensively analyze humor is not that helpful I don't think. Definitely good if you want to get used to writing funny things. I used the class to test out a whole bunch of different forms I don't usually write in, so that was fun.
This is an amazing class. I feel like I've never thought so critically about comedy, and simultaneously I've never been so carefree and silly in my coursework. Highly recommend!
A greater understanding of humor writing and the intricacies of humor.
This was an amazing class. I learned so much about writing humor on the sentence level and the story level. I also learned what its looks like to work hard in a class because you love doing it.
I learned a lot about the technicality behind writing humor: both the rules and how to break them.

You will learn how to write, evaluate, and appreciate humor. You will also learn about your own sense of humor, how to define it and write it better. You will also just have a blast and feel like you are in community with your peers by the end of it all.
I learned how to write humor and write in general.
I have developed a greater understanding of what I personally find funny, how to articulate humor, sentence structure that adds to humor, and a better voice as a writer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: Prof. Wepler put a lot of attention and care into this course and it is very clear. Every day is planned meticulously and not a minute is wasted. There are so many avenues to receive feedback on assignments.
weaknesses: none, although grading seems a bit arbitrary at times but I think that's inevitable in a class like this

Strengths: getting to practice writing. Peer workshops and feedback. some funny readings. 
weaknesses: some class discussions (non-workshop days) were not super exciting. there's only so much you can say about a humor piece other than "it was funny" or "this part was funny". Especially on days where I didn't love the readings. Prof. Wepler also has a very distinct sense of humor, and some grades seemed to reflect not the quality of the work, but whether or not he liked it.

It's super engaging and each class teaches you something new in a fun and rigorous environment. Not many weaknesses I could call out aside from the fact that it's quite focused upon a narrow band of humor writing for the page, so if someone is looking for writing like screenplays or other formats then this isn't really the course for that.
One strength is honestly the selection of the group. I dont know how it works, but the people were great. I also loved how varied the activities were as well as the assignments.

Strengths: 
well-organized
receive so much clear feedback in multiple formats
so many opportunities to practice week to week and day to day
so much fun
Ryan loves his job

Weaknesses: 
people shouldn't be able to use their laptops, it really detracted from the classes
Ryan was an amazing, attentive, smart, and thoughtful instructor. He made the course worthwhile. I think it would've been fun to do more writers-room type stuff.
The course structure was phenomenal, I loved how we workshopped other students' work, if I could change anything I would have liked the opportunity to edit earlier essays for a grade.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes absolutely! One of the best courses I've taken at Yale, by far. It is stimulating, engaging, and a very fun class. It is a lot of work, but the work is interesting and a great brain break from your other assignments.

Up to you, obviously. But I would say yes, albeit maybe with slightly lowered expectations than where you're probably at right now. Do I think I learned a ton? Not really. Did I enjoy this course? Most of the time. It was a good excuse to write funny stuff every week. I befriended several people in the class. But I think it's one of those courses that sounds more fun than it actually is.
I recommend this class to anyone. Anyone who is interested in being funny and willing to turn being funny less into a personality trait and more into a practice should take this class.

Extremely. If you enjoy writing and stretching your creative and humorous muscle, this class is a joy. The work never really feels like work and you get to explore your own sense of humor and comedy as a whole with a fresh lens.
I would recommend this to anyone and everyone who likes writing and likes laughing.

Absolutely! Its a very high workload class (in terms of pure amount of content you need to be outputting), but its totally worth it. Id advise not taking during a heavy semester, but its such a great class if you enjoy writing humor and want to measurably improve!

yes! I had the best time. I also feel like this course can be enjoyed by people with and without experience. It is such a great way to practice and learn to appreciate writing, and also helps you focus on such specific skills, down the word and stance level of writing. I think that a lot of writing can benefit from the attention to detail this class teaches you.

This course was an excellent introduction the humor writing. There was a lot of variety of exercises, strategies, and genres assigned. It was fulfilling to see my growth and my peers growth in the class.
I would. It's fun, hard, and extremely informative.

Absolutely, whether students are interested in comedy or not, this course was instrumental to developing my voice as a writer across all disciplines, and has probably been the class I have learned the most from during my time at Yale.
